string.last_approved_text: Emperor seat
Emperor seat

When a ruler takes on the title of duke, it signifies the start of a great ruling dynasty that is expected to survive the ages through succession. As with preceding faction ranks, a duke’s accrued powers further increase their capacity to field military forces, order civic assignments, and appoint ministers.

campaign_localised_strings.string: When a ruler takes on the title of duke, it signifies the start of a great ruling dynasty that is expected to survive the ages through succession. As with preceding faction ranks, a duke’s accrued powers further increase their capacity to field military forces, order civic assignments, and appoint ministers.

string.last_approved_text: A warlord can only attain the title of king by achieving near-unrivalled authority, thus bringing themselves one step away from proclaiming themselves emperor. Having reached this upper echelon of power, a king faces the inevitable consequence of being challenged by the most powerful opposing rivals.

campaign_localised_strings.string: A warlord can only attain the title of king by achieving near-unrivalled authority, thus bringing themselves one step away from proclaiming themselves emperor. string.last_approved_text: Of the numerous grades of aristocrat in Chinese nobility, a marquis is the highest rank within a fiefdom. Having earned the utmost grace and favour of their followers, they enjoy further expanded military and civic powers that include the ability to propose alliances with other warlords.

campaign_localised_strings.string: Of the numerous grades of aristocrat in Chinese nobility, a marquis is the highest rank within a fiefdom. Having earned the utmost grace and favour of their followers, they enjoy further expanded military and civic powers that include the ability to propose alliances with other warlords.

string.last_approved_text: Just as a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, every leader must start somewhere. As a noble, your faction leader is no normal member of the body politic, but one who has risen through the ranks of the community to wield considerable martial powers.

string.last_approved_text:
Here you can deploy retinues to either create a new army, or to add additional retinues to an existing army.

[[img:help_mode_context_compatibility]][[/img]] This icon will tell you information about the [[b]]compatibility[[/b]] of a general with the generals already present in the army. Try to foster positive relationships by deploying compatible generals into existing armies.

[[img:help_mode_hud_treasury]][[/img]] Shows the [[b]]re-deployment[[/b]] cost for the entire retinue. All of the units persist, even when not deployed, and you will have to pay to [[b]]deploy them again[[/b]], but they will retain their [[b]]experience ranks[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_army_upkeep]][[/img]] This number represents the [[b]]upkeep cost[[/b]] for the entire retinue. Make sure your per-turn income can afford the additional cost. Maintaining [[b]]positive income[[/b]] is vital for a healthy economy.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
Here you can deploy retinues to either create a new army, or to add additional retinues to an existing army.

[[img:help_mode_context_compatibility]][[/img]] This icon will tell you information about the [[b]]compatibility[[/b]] of a general with the generals already present in the army. Try to foster positive relationships by deploying compatible generals into existing armies.

[[img:help_mode_hud_treasury]][[/img]] Shows the [[b]]re-deployment[[/b]] cost for the entire retinue. All of the units persist, even when not deployed, and you will have to pay to [[b]]deploy them again[[/b]], but they will retain their [[b]]experience ranks[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_army_upkeep]][[/img]] This number represents the [[b]]upkeep cost[[/b]] for the entire retinue. Make sure your per-turn income can afford the additional cost. Maintaining [[b]]positive income[[/b]] is vital for a healthy economy.

string.last_approved_text: Retinue Deployment

All effects [[b]]acting on[[/b]] the army and [[b]]away from[[/b]] it are displayed here. Effects on the army are summarised by different icons associated with effects [[b]]from generals[[/b]], [[b]] territory[[/b]], and its [[b]]faction[[/b]]. Effects coming from the military force itself are part of the faction category.\n\nAdditionally, there can be other special effects active, often temporarily, such as effects that come into play when sacking a settlement.

string.last_approved_text: Army Effects

The number of [[b]]action points[[/b]] represents an army's movement extent and its ability to traverse terrain or to switch into [[b]]stances[[/b]]. Stances require a certain amount of action points [[b]]remaining[[/b]] to be activated. Special stances like [[b]]ambush[[/b]] or [[b]]encampment[[/b]] disable movement after they are assumed.

[[img:help_mode_army_upkeep]][[/img]] shows the summary of its [[b]]upkeep[[/b]] costs, which can help you quickly identify your most expensive forces. These will typically the most valuable armies, but it might be worth considering [[b]]disbanding[[/b]] some of its units if they are not needed at this time. This will help to ease the load on your economy.

string.last_approved_text: This button allows you to [[b]]activate recruitment[[/b]]. You can [[b]]deploy[[/b]] additional retinues or [[b]]recruit[[/b]] units into existing ones. This is only possible in your own territory. Newly-recruited units will spawn at a [[b]]fraction[[/b]] of their maximum health and will then replenish and muster to full strength over a period of time.\n\nRecruitment is [[b]]disabled[[/b]] on the first turn of a campaign.

campaign_localised_strings.string: This button allows you to [[b]]activate recruitment[[/b]]. You can [[b]]deploy[[/b]] additional retinues or [[b]]recruit[[/b]] units into existing ones. This is only possible in your own territory. Newly-recruited units will spawn at a [[b]]fraction[[/b]] of their maximum health and will then replenish and muster to full strength over a period of time.\n\nRecruitment is [[b]]disabled[[/b]] on the first turn of a campaign.

string.last_approved_text:
These are the units available for recruitment at this time. Recruited units are [[b]]persistent[[/b]] and will remain part of the retinue even when destroyed (after which they will re-emerge following a period of [[b]]convalescence[[/b]]) or when the retinue is [[b]]not deployed[[/b]].

When recruiting, consider [[b]]army composition[[/b]] to identify which units are most required. A [[b]]balanced[[/b]] army consists of strong [[b]]melee units[[/b]] (equipped with spears or swords and shields), some [[b]]ranged units[[/b]] such as archers, and some cavalry units for mobile [[b]]flanking manoeuvres[[/b]].

Be mindful of cost of recruitment and upkeep for the unit - your economy must be robust enough to carry the weight of the investment.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
These are the units available for recruitment at this time. Recruited units are [[b]]persistent[[/b]] and will remain part of the retinue even when destroyed (after which they will re-emerge following a period of [[b]]convalescence[[/b]]) or when the retinue is [[b]]not deployed[[/b]].

When recruiting, consider [[b]]army composition[[/b]] to identify which units are most required. A [[b]]balanced[[/b]] army consists of strong [[b]]melee units[[/b]] (equipped with spears or swords and shields), some [[b]]ranged units[[/b]] such as archers, and some cavalry units for mobile [[b]]flanking manoeuvres[[/b]].

Be mindful of cost of recruitment and upkeep for the unit - your economy must be robust enough to carry the weight of the investment.

string.last_approved_text: Unit Recruitment

This is the display for [[b]]retinues[[/b]] and [[b]]units[[/b]] in this army. Units are grouped into retinues, with each army consisting of up to three of them.

By clicking the [[b]]recruit[[/b]] button, you can deploy additional retinues into a force after activating recruitment, which will also allow you to recruit further units into existing retinues.

Retinues are commanded by a [[b]]retinue commander[[/b]] – all units within it are [[b]]loyal[[/b]] to this character. If they fall in battle, the retinue’s units will suffer a [[b]]morale penalty[[/b]]. If a retinue commander [[b]]dies[[/b]], he can be replaced by another character.

Units in retinues are [[b]]persistent[[/b]]; this means that when a retinue is [[b]]recalled[[/b]], its units will remain off the map. When [[b]]re-deploying[[/b]] a retinue, all of its existing units will reappear, replete with their [[b]]experience ranks[[/b]]. [[b]]Re-deployment[[/b]] requires recruitment costs to be payed again, but there are ways to reduce them (via [[b]]{{tr:technologies}}[[/b]], for example).

Persistence also means that destroyed units will [[b]]convalesce[[/b]] and then re-appear and muster again, without the need to pay again for their recruitment.

string.last_approved_text:
[[img:help_mode_army_supplies]][[/img]] [[b]]Military supplies[[/b]] represent an army's ability to re-supply while out in the field. High levels of supply provide a [[b]]morale[[/b]] bonus, while low levels create a [[b]]morale[[/b]] penalty. Most importantly, once supplies run out, armies will suffer from [[b]]attrition[[/b]].

Supplies are heavily influenced by the current [[b]]terrain[[/b]] (arid deserts consume more supplies than lush plains) and [[b]]climate[[/b]]. Additionally, supplies are generally replenished when on [[b]]own territory[[/b]] and [[b]]allied territory[[/b]], but will be severely depleted when in [[b]]hostile territory[[/b]].

Be mindful when planning offensive campaigns deep into enemy territory or when planning to [[b]]besiege[[/b]] a settlement – you may wish to ensure additional supply bonuses before committing.

These things can assist you during offensive campaigns:
Characters with high [[b]]cunning[[/b]], such as [[b]]strategists[[/b]], provide significant bonuses to supplies, so bringing them along on offensive campaigns can be very beneficial.

Certain [[b]]buildings[[/b]], such as [[b]]Watchtower Garrisons[[/b]], provide a supply bonus into adjacent enemy territory. Consider constructing these in frontline territories.

Certain [[b]]skills[[/b]] or [[b]]ancillaries[[/b]] can also provide valuable bonuses to the character involved.

string.last_approved_text: Military Supplies

These are the control options and commands for this army.

[[img:help_mode_return_to_settlement]][[/img]] This will swap your view back to the panel of the settlement your army is garrisoning.

[[img:help_mode_army_context_replace]][[/img]] [[b]]Replace unit[[/b]] allows you to replace one existing unit with another. Since retinues can only contain a maximum number of [[b]]6 units[[/b]], replacing existing units with more powerful ones is an important strategy for the later stages of the game.

[[img:help_mode_army_context_disband]][[/img]] [[b]]Disband unit[[/b]] will break up this unit and disband its troops, which can be important when trying to save money from [[b]]upkeep[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_army_context_stance]][[/img]] This allows you to switch [[b]]stances[[/b]]. [[b]]Ambush[[/b]] stance can be an efficient choice when laying traps for the enemy and will create battles where the enemy is at a disadvantage. [[b]]Encamp[[/b]] means your army sets up camp and will defend itself with an improvised fort if attacked.

[[img:help_mode_army_context_split]][[/img]] [[b]]Split[[/b]] will extract this retinue from the current army, effectively creating an entirely new army.

[[img:help_mode_army_context_undeploy]][[/img]] [[b]]Recall[[/b]] will remove this retinue from the map. However, its units will [[b]]persist[[/b]] and can be [[b]]re-deployed[[/b]] (at a cost).

[[img:help_mode_army_context_swap]][[/img]] This button allows you to [[b]]replace the retinue[[/b]] with another one, taking its place within the army.

string.last_approved_text: Retinues & Units

Victory in a settlement battle is determined by [[b]]victory points[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_battle_capture_points]][[/img]] Once the attacker is in control of the victory point by [[b]]capturing[[/b]] it with his own units, this number will start to [[b]]tick down[[/b]]. As long as the defender is in control of the victory point, this number will remain [[b]]static[[/b]].

Once this number [[b]]reaches 0[[/b]], the attacker has won the battle and captured the city.

Once this number [[b]]reaches 0[[/b]], the attacker has won the battle and captured the city.

string.last_approved_text: Capture Score

This value shows the relative [[b]]destruction level[[/b]] of this settlement.

[[img:help_mode_battle_destruction_level]][[/img]] [[b]]Destruction level[[/b]] increases when buildings are being [[b]]set on fire[[/b]] and when areas of the settlement are being [[b]]destroyed[[/b]].

High levels of destruction will cause a [[b]]morale penalty[[/b]] for the defender.

string.last_approved_text: Settlement Destruction

This button allows you to initiate [[b]]duels[[/b]] with characters in an enemy alliance. Winning duels will have a significant impact on the morale of forces and can be a deciding factor in battle.

Pressing this button will show you a list of enemies you can [[b]]challenge[[/b]]. For a duel to occur, a challenge must be [[b]]accepted[[/b]], and in some cases, the enemy might [[b]]reject[[/b]] it.

For each character you can challenge, the possible [[b]]outcome[[/b]] of the duel will be highlighted. Some duels are about life or death and will only conclude when one of the combatants falls, while others are merely concerned with demonstrating one's battle prowess, or about the honourable contest between duellists.

By default, other soldiers will respect a duel and will [[b]]not interfere[[/b]]. You can order units to attack the enemy duellist; this will be seen as a [[b]]dishonourable[[/b]] act and will have a negative morale effect on your forces, but it can be the only way to save your hero's life.

You can also [[b]]run away[[/b]] from an ongoing duel – an equally dishonourable act.

Buffing your hero with other characters while a duel is ongoing is [[b]]not dishonourable[[/b]], however, and can be a strong strategy for improving your duellist.

This is the status panel for an [[b]]ongoing duel[[/b]], which allows you to keep track of its [[b]]progress[[/b]] and [[b]]strength comparison[[/b]]. If your hero is falling behind, it might be best to [[b]]interfere[[/b]] or [[b]]withdraw[[/b]] from the duel.\n\n(Romance mode only) Also consider [[b]]buffing[[/b]] your duellist by using the [[b]]special abilities[[/b]] of other heroes in your army.

These are a unit's or character's special abilities.

[[img:help_mode_battle_context_formations]][[/img]] Units are able to enter [[b]]formations[[/b]] that provide tactical abilities for certain situations. Investigate the [[b]]tooltip[[/b]] of a given formation to learn more about them.

[[img:help_mode_battle_special_ability]][[/img]] (Romance mode only) Characters can unlock powerful [[b]]special abilities[[/b]] that can change the course of battle. Depending on a character's background, these abilities can cause [[b]]direct damage[[/b]], while other abilities are either [[b]]buffs[[/b]] for friendly troops, or [[b]]debuffs[[/b]] that can be used against the enemy.

[[img:help_mode_battle_skirmish]][[/img]] [[b]]Skirmish[[/b]] mode is available to most [[b]]ranged units[[/b]]. It means that the unit will try to [[b]]stay away from enemies[[/b]] and will retreat if enemies come too close.

string.last_approved_text: Unit Abilities

These are general [[b]]commands[[/b]] for the units in your army.

[[img:help_mode_battle_context_run]][[/img]] [[b]]Run speed[[/b]] is turned on by default. It can be worth to [[b]]turn it off[[/b]], however, if you need to prevent units becoming [[b]]fatigued[[/b]] while travelling over the map.

[[img:help_mode_battle_context_halt]][[/img]] [[b]]Halt[[/b]] instantly [[b]]cancels all orders[[/b]] and makes a unit [[b]]stop[[/b]] all movement or attacks. This can be used to stop artillery from continuing fire into the settlement during a siege battle.

[[img:help_mode_battle_context_toggle_group]][[/img]][[b]]Toggle group[[/b]] generates a [[b]]control group[[/b]] incorporating all [[b]]selected units[[/b]].

[[img:help_mode_battle_context_guard]][[/img]][[b]]Guard mode[[/b]] can be activated to order a unit to [[b]]stand its ground[[/b]]. This means a unit will [[b]]not pursuit[[/b]] its enemy but rather [[b]]defend[[/b]] its current position.

[[img:help_mode_battle_context_melee_mode]][[/img]] [[b]]Melee mode[[/b]] orders a unit to attack in melee instead of its ranged weapon. This can be useful to [[b]]conserve ammunition[[/b]], or if you want units to [[b]]charge[[/b]] into the enemy.

string.last_approved_text: Unit Commands

When you [[b]]capture[[/b]] wounded enemy characters in battle, you may [[b]]decide their fate[[/b]] afterwards.

You can [[b]]execute[[/b]] them, which will also [[b]]confiscate[[/b]] their belongings but might [[b]]anger[[/b]] those with whom the character is on good terms.

You can choose to [[b]]release[[/b]] them, which will return them to their faction; your enemies will retain a general and the spared general will be [[b]]grateful[[/b]] to you. This is a good way to improve [[b]]relationships[[/b]] with enemy characters.

Finally, in certain cases, you may [[b]]employ[[/b]] the captured character. This is not possible, however, if they hold a [[b]]grudge[[/b]] against you.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
When you [[b]]capture[[/b]] wounded enemy characters in battle, you may [[b]]decide their fate[[/b]] afterwards.

You can [[b]]execute[[/b]] them, which will also [[b]]confiscate[[/b]] their belongings but might [[b]]anger[[/b]] those with whom the character is on good terms.

You can choose to [[b]]release[[/b]] them, which will return them to their faction; your enemies will retain a general and the spared general will be [[b]]grateful[[/b]] to you. This is a good way to improve [[b]]relationships[[/b]] with enemy characters.

Finally, in certain cases, you may [[b]]employ[[/b]] the captured character. This is not possible, however, if they hold a [[b]]grudge[[/b]] against you.

string.last_approved_text: Battle Captives

Your general’s [[b]]special abilities[[/b]] can be used in battle to great effect. Some might be passive, inherent abilities, providing constant benefits to them, their retinue or their entire army. Others might be special skills such as sword strikes or resistance/immunity developed during their career.

Others might be special skills such as sword strikes or resistance/immunity developed during their career.

string.last_approved_text:
Each general has inherent strengths and weaknesses. Each attribute represents a different approach to strategy and tactics, which should be taken into account when you are planning.

[[img:help_mode_character_attribute_expertise]][[/img]] [[b]]Expertise[[/b]] is your general's understanding of craftsmanship and industry. Characters with high expertise are good candidates for building up infrastructure in your {{tr:map_provinces}} as {{tr:governors}}. They also have a greater evasion and defensive capabilities in battles.

[[img:help_mode_character_attribute_resolve]][[/img]] [[b]]Resolve[[/b]] improves the endurance of both your generals and the people. Characters with high resolve are great at boosting population growth in your {{tr:map_provinces}} when assigned as {{tr:governor}}. This is especially valuable in {{tr:map_provinces}} focusing on [[b]]peasantry[[/b]] income.

[[img:help_mode_character_attribute_cunning]][[/img]] [[b]]Cunning[[/b]] is the wise use of strategy and planning. Use characters with high cunning to support longer campaigns in enemy territory or when besieging enemy settlements. They are also more efficient when leading ranged retinues.

[[img:help_mode_character_attribute_instinct]][[/img]] [[b]]Instinct[[/b]] is your general's capability as a military commander. Use characters with high instinct to oversee recruitment in your armies. They are also stronger in melee combat, so characters focusing on this type of combat should have high instinct.

[[img:help_mode_character_attribute_authority]][[/img]] [[b]]Authority[[/b]] is your general's ability to lead others on and off the battlefield. Faction leaders and other [[b]]people in power[[/b]] are more effective when they have high authority as they increase satisfaction of all other characters. Their [[b]]morale[[/b]] bonus on their retinue is beneficial when defending against overwhelming forces.

string.last_approved_text: Character Rank

This panel gives an overview of the relationships between this character and others.

[[b]]Relationships[[/b]] are primarily driven by character [[b]]traits[[/b]]. Each character has opinions about other traits, so characters with matching or suitable traits will tend to get on well with each other. [[b]]Opinions[[/b]] determine how characters feel about one another, so investigate their traits and the associated opinions.

In order to forge relationships, characters must be involved with each other, either by being in the same army, location together, or if a character interacts with his faction leader.

[[i]]You can {{tr:left_click_icon}} characters in this overview to visit their panels in order to gain a better understanding of this network of relationships.[[/i]]

[[img:help_mode_character_satisfaction]][[/img]] indicates a character's [[b]]satisfaction[[/b]]. string.last_approved_text:
The [[b]]family tree[[/b]] is where the sweeping dynastic actions take place. Secure your inheritance by [[b]]adopting[[/b]] characters into your family, managing [[b]]marriages[[/b]] between your family members and courtiers, or [[b]]seek a spouse[[/b]] for yourself.

Both the faction leader and their heir have a strong impact on faction-wide bonuses (along with the prime minister), so managing the succession is important. Be careful, however, as if one of your sons defects he may be able to launch a [[b]]civil war[[/b]].

[[i]]You can pan around the family tree by holding down {{tr:left_click_icon}} and moving the mouse.[[/i]]

string.last_approved_text: Generals & Nobles

[[b]]Administrators[[/b]] are your local representatives who each govern a {{tr:map_province}}. They will bring unique effects to their commandery and also increase the maximum number of armies you can field.

• Administrators can be deployed as generals and lead armies elsewhere, but if they are not generals they will only be able to field the [[b]]garrison[[/b]] within their assigned {{tr:map_province}}.
• Powerful administrators, especially [[b]]ambitious[[/b]] ones, may request greater independence.
• Administrators greatly decrease [[b]]corruption[[/b]] in their lands.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
[[b]]Administrators[[/b]] are your local representatives who each govern a {{tr:map_province}}. They will bring unique effects to their commandery and also increase the maximum number of armies you can field.

• Powerful administrators, especially [[b]]ambitious[[/b]] ones, may request greater independence.
• Administrators greatly decrease [[b]]corruption[[/b]] in their lands.

string.last_approved_text:
These are the [[b]]people in power[[/b]] within your faction, who will have a big impact on your faction’s [[b]]bonuses[[/b]], so consider the candidates wisely. Faction heirs must be part of your family, so adopting capable characters with beneficial bonuses is an important dynastic strategy.

Build strong synergies between these positions to maximise the efficiency of these bonuses.

Inspect the tooltips for [[b]]character background[[/b]] to find information about faction-wide effects when they are faction leader, faction heir, or prime minister.

campaign_localised_strings.string:

Build strong synergies between these positions to maximise the efficiency of these bonuses.

Inspect the tooltips for [[b]]character background[[/b]] to find information about faction-wide effects when they are faction leader, faction heir, or prime minister.

string.last_approved_text: People in Power

This is your [[b]]Faction Leader[[/b]], who together with the 'Lords of Virtue' make up the [[b]]'People in Power'[[/b]] within your faction. They have a big impact on its [[b]]bonuses[[/b]], so consider the candidates wisely. The Lords of Virtue are the 'Lord of the People', the 'Lord of the Land' and the 'Lord of Heaven'. These positions must be unlocked through [[b]]reforms[[/b]].

Build strong synergies between these positions to maximise the efficiency of their bonuses.

Inspect the tooltips for [[b]]character background[[/b]], in order to learn about faction-wide effects when they're amongst the [[b]]People in Power[[/b]].

string.last_approved_text: People in Power

Ministers hold [[b]]positions[[/b]] and form the body of your faction [[b]]council[[/b]]. Each position brings unique effects and characters, especially powerful ones, will desire to progress their career by occupying more prestigious positions.

• [[b]]Ministers[[/b]] who defect from your faction automatically start a [[b]]civil war[[/b]].
• Characters will be [[b]]jealous[[/b]] of lower-ranking characters in higher offices.
• Each office has a suggested maximum rank – a character with a higher rank than that will start to feel dissatisfied and start to aim for a higher position.
• Inspect each position to understand its relation to a character’s rank and satisfaction.

[[img:help_mode_hud_council]][[/img]] The [[b]]council[[/b]] can be invoked from the main HUD and will provide missions, depending on the office and the background of the character currently holding it.

They can be made part of your family by [[b]]adoption[[/b]] or through [[b]]marriage[[/b]] to your own offspring.\n\nBeing part of the faction leader's family makes a character more satisfied, but can create [[b]]competition for inheritance[[/b]] and might upset other siblings.

They can be made part of your family by [[b]]adoption[[/b]] or through [[b]]marriage[[/b]] to your own offspring.\n\nBeing part of the faction leader's family makes a character more satisfied, but can create [[b]]competition for inheritance[[/b]] and might upset other siblings.

string.last_approved_text:
These are your diplomatic options with other factions.

[[b]]War[[/b]] gives various options for declaring war, and for calling in allies or vassals for help, or to support a vassal’s independence.

[[b]]Peace[[/b]] allows you engage in peace negotiations, either alone or in the name of your alliance.

[[b]]Trade and marriage[[/b]] offers options for trading goods, diplomatic payments, and official trade agreements. You can also marry here for diplomatic reasons.

[[b]]Alliances[[/b]] is concerned with coalitions and alliances. [[b]]Coalitions[[/b]] are groups of factions that defend each other when attacked but operate freely in offensive wars. [[b]]Alliances[[/b]], on the other hand, work more closely together, and make decisions based on the votes of each ally.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
These are your diplomatic options with other factions.

[[b]]War[[/b]] gives various options for declaring war, and for calling in allies or vassals for help, or to support a vassal’s independence.

[[b]]Peace[[/b]] allows you engage in peace negotiations, either alone or in the name of your alliance.

[[b]]Trade and marriage[[/b]] offers options for trading goods, diplomatic payments, and official trade agreements. You can also marry here for diplomatic reasons.

[[b]]Alliances[[/b]] is concerned with coalitions and alliances. [[b]]Coalitions[[/b]] are groups of factions that defend each other when attacked but operate freely in offensive wars. [[b]]Alliances[[/b]], on the other hand, work more closely together, and make decisions based on the votes of each ally.

string.last_approved_text: Diplomatic Deals

These are the [[b]]existing deals[[/b]] with this faction. Review these deals by inspecting the tooltips for each item.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_cancel_deal]][[/img]] Deals can be [[b]]cancelled[[/b]] by pressing this button. Be mindful that, generally speaking, cancelling deals will be seen as an act that reduces your [[b]]trustworthiness[[/b]].

If no deals are present with this faction, this list will be empty.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
These are the [[b]]existing deals[[/b]] with this faction. Review these deals by inspecting the tooltips for each item.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_cancel_deal]][[/img]] Deals can be [[b]]cancelled[[/b]] by pressing this button. Be mindful that, generally speaking, cancelling deals will be seen as an act that reduces your [[b]]trustworthiness[[/b]].

If no deals are present with this faction, this list will be empty.

string.last_approved_text: Existing deals

Select a faction to review the diplomatic situation from their perspective. This will also change information on the map to their point of view.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_factions_attitude]][[/img]] [[b]]Diplomatic attitudes[[/b]] towards others is illustrated by this icon; inspect its tooltip for detailed information about a faction’s attitude towards you. When you select another faction, these icons and tooltips will change to respresent every other faction’s attitude towards the one selected.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_factions_treaties]][[/img]] You will also see key [[b]]diplomatic treaties[[/b]] between you and every other faction (or from the selected faction's perspective).

Use this to understand if a faction is liked or disliked by others - the enemy of your enemy is your friend, after all.

This also helps to understand the impact of your own actions – your enemies’ friends will not approve of offensive actions against each other, for example.

[[i]]• {{tr:Left_click_icon}} to select a faction
• {{tr:Right_click_icon}} to start negotiating[[/i]]

campaign_localised_strings.string:
Select a faction to review the diplomatic situation from their perspective. This will also change information on the map to their point of view.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_factions_attitude]][[/img]] [[b]]Diplomatic attitudes[[/b]] towards others is illustrated by this icon; inspect its tooltip for detailed information about a faction’s attitude towards you. When you select another faction, these icons and tooltips will change to respresent every other faction’s attitude towards the one selected.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_factions_treaties]][[/img]] You will also see key [[b]]diplomatic treaties[[/b]] between you and every other faction (or from the selected faction's perspective).

Use this to understand if a faction is liked or disliked by others - the enemy of your enemy is your friend, after all.

This also helps to understand the impact of your own actions – your enemies’ friends will not approve of offensive actions against each other, for example.

[[i]]• {{tr:Left_click_icon}} to select a faction
• {{tr:Right_click_icon}} to start negotiating[[/i]]

string.last_approved_text: Known Factions

[[b]]Diplomacy[[/b]] is about forging alliances and isolating enemies. Negotiating preferable deals for goods, land, or trade is only one part of diplomacy. The diplomatic landscape – the [[b]]attitude[[/b]] of factions to each other – is vital, so be sure to inspect these relationships well in order to select potential friends or war targets.

Diplomacy has two basic functions: 
Choose [[b]]'Negotiate'[[/b]] if you want to engage in detailed dialogue with another faction to propose [[b]]deals[[/b]] or review existing ones.

[[b]]'Quick Deal'[[/b]], on the other hand, allows you to pick a diplomatic deal first, then investigate who would be willing to sign it with you.

Ensure that you exploit all your [[b]]trade agreements[[/b]] slots, but keep in mind that they are limited, so try to find only the most valuable trade partners. The income gained is determined by the total GDP of your faction, your trade partner, and the relative [[b]]trade influence[[/b]] of the two factions.

string.last_approved_text: Diplomacy Help

All items currently under negotiation are shown here.

Review the terms of your current negotiation before making a proposal.

Each term has a [[b]]deal value[[/b]] for your negotiation partner – hovering over a specific term will give further information about this value.

If the terms are beneficial to the faction leader with whom you are negotiating, it will receive a higher value.

Most important factors are:
• Diplomatic relations to other factions
• Military strength
• Military situation and strategic situation.

A summary of your [[b]]diplomatic treaties[[/b]] with other factions.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_treaties_war]][[/img]] These are the factions you are [[b]]at war[[/b]] with.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_treaties_vassal]][[/img]] These are your [[b]]vassals[[/b]], who can be asked to join you in your wars and who will pay regular tribute to you. Watch out for the [[b]]personality[[/b]] of those faction leaders to gauge their reliability and understand how best to keep them in line.

[[img:help_mode_diplomacy_treaties_trade]][[/img]] The number of [[b]]trade agreements[[/b]] you can sign is limited by your faction rank - but you can unlock more trade agreements with the right {{tr:technologies}}. Income from [[b]]trade[[/b]] is determined both by factions' gross income each turn and by a comparison of each other’s trade influence; the more influential you are, the more you will gain from these deals.

string.last_approved_text: Quick Deal

The goal of your campaign is to [[b]]unite China[[/b]] under the rule of an emperor worthy of the mandate.\n\nThis can be achieved by [[b]]proclaiming[[/b]] yourself emperor or empress once you have accumulated enough [[b]]prestige[[/b]]. Other warlords and leaders may strike first, however, and proclaim themselves ruler before you. In this case, you must capture their [[b]]capitals[[/b]] – their seats of power – to achieve victory.

string.last_approved_text:
Important information to be considered before making strategic moves is displayed here.

[[img:help_mode_province_money]][[/img]] Your [[b]]treasury[[/b]] is one of your most important resources – make sure to maintain a positive income each season. Sometimes, it may be wise to recall existing forces to save unit [[b]]upkeep[[/b]]. Consider aggressive measures such as sacking and looting, and make sure you have a long-term plan for your economy based on [[b]]synergies[[/b]] between settlements and buildings.

[[img:help_mode_province_food]][[/img]] [[b]]Food[[/b]] is produced and consumed in all your {{tr:map_provinces}}, but only your [[b]]faction-wide balance[[/b]] will have an effect. Increasing the surplus regenerates [[b]]reserves[[/b]] in all your {{tr:map_provinces}} and gives a bonus to income from the peasantry. Faction-wide food shortages will deplete [[b]]reserves[[/b]] in all your {{tr:map_provinces}}. Make sure you have dedicated [[b]]breadbasket {{tr:map_provinces}}[[/b]] or spread out food production across your territory. Maintaining food production is a critical strategy.

[[img:help_mode_hud_seasons]][[/img]] Consider the [[b]]seasons[[/b]] when planning your strategy; during the [[b]]harvest[[/b]], income from [[b]]peasantry[[/b]] is increased, and during [[b]]winter[[/b]], armies will naturally consume more military supplies - especially in cold climates.

[[img:help_mode_hud_resources]][[/img]] These are the [[b]]resources[[/b]] your faction has gained access to. They are available [[b]]faction-wide[[/b]] and will enable construction of certain [[b]]buildings[[/b]]. Resources do not have effects on their own. [[b]]Trade agreements[[/b]] with other factions through diplomacy will share access to these resources.

string.last_approved_text: Night Battle

This shows the outcome of the battle if [[b]]delegated[[/b]] to your advisors. Their predictions are always [[b]]accurate[[/b]] and a predicted victory will always result in the stated outcome.\n\nThe bar shows a [[b]]strength comparison[[/b]] of both armies. If the bar is heavily in your favour, it means that the strength of your force – its [[b]]quality[[/b]] and its [[b]]quantity[[/b]] – is superior to that of the enemy. This does [[b]]not[[/b]] always guarantee victory, however. If the enemy's forces generally counter your own units, then even an inferior opponent might be victorious. In these cases, your advisors’ prediction of defeat will remain [[b]]accurate[[/b]].

string.last_approved_text: Battle Prediction

This option means [[b]]reinforcements[[/b]] will join you in battle – either another army of [[b]]yours[[/b]] or an [[b]]ally[[/b]]. In either case, [[b]]reinforcements[[/b]] will gradually enter the battlefield with a [[b]]delay[[/b]].

You can either attempt to [[b]]re-group[[/b]] and unify your army or treat your reinforcements as an independent [[b]]wing[[/b]] that can operate on its own. It all depends on your [[b]]strategy[[/b]] and the units in the [[b]]main force[[/b]] and your [[b]]reinforcements[[/b]].

string.last_approved_text: Enemy Army
Your Army

These are the bespoke options for fighting [[b]]sieges[[/b]].

[[b]]Starve out[[/b]] continues the siege in [[b]]unfortified settlements[[/b]], such as [[b]]resource settlements[[/b]] or small towns without walls, without launching an assault – the besieged force will eventually surrender or try to sally out to break the siege.

[[b]]Continue siege[[/b]] continues to besiege a [[b]]walled settlement[[/b]] where siege engines can be constructed in order to assault the walls.

[[b]]Demand surrender[[/b]] is possible if there is an army [[b]]stationed[[/b]] inside the enemy settlement. [[b]]Demanding surrender[[/b]] enables the besieged force to [[b]]retreat[[/b]] and granting you the settlement without a fight. If you are the defender, you can also [[b]]offer surrender[[/b]] in this manner.

[[b]]Break siege[[/b]] cancels the siege and [[b]]withdraws[[/b]] your force from around the settlement.

[[img:help_mode_prebattle_siege_attrition]][[/img]] Turns until forces in this settlement will begin to suffer [[b]]attrition[[/b]]. Larger stockpiles of [[b]]reserves[[/b]] within the besieged settlement will increase this number.

[[img:help_mode_prebattle_siege_barricades]][[/img]] Number of [[b]]barricades[[/b]] available to the defender. These are [[b]]destructible obstacles[[/b]] which can make it more difficult to [[b]]manoeuvre[[/b]] through the settlement.

string.last_approved_text: Siege Information

[[b]]Start Battle[[/b]] will enable you to fight the battle manually. Gauge the [[b]]strength comparison[[/b]] above to get an estimate of its difficulty.\n\n[[b]]Delegate[[/b]] gives command over to your advisors and officers, and automatically resolves the battle. The [[b]]outcome[[/b]] will always match your advisors' [[b]]prediction[[/b]], so be mindful when delegating battles where they [[b]]predict a defeat[[/b]].

This is the main [[b]]settlement administration[[/b]] chain; it determines the settlement level of the commandery capital. Increasing the administrative level can provide valuable prestige and also enable more [[b]]building slots[[/b]] and a higher [[b]]population capacity[[/b]].\n\nHigher levels require the provision of [[b]]food[[/b]], so make sure you have farms or other food-producing buildings available.

campaign_localised_strings.string: This is the main [[b]]settlement administration[[/b]] chain; it determines the settlement level of the commandery capital. Increasing the administrative level can provide valuable prestige and also enable more [[b]]building slots[[/b]] and a higher [[b]]population capacity[[/b]].\n\nHigher levels require the provision of [[b]]food[[/b]], so make sure you have farms or other food-producing buildings available.

string.last_approved_text: This is the capital of this commandery, currently owned by another faction. Larger settlements will be generally more difficult to besiege, so be mindful when picking your targets. Owning the commandery capital is the key to fully exploiting your lands to gain the greatest benefits.

string.last_approved_text: Settlement Administration (Not owned)
Settlement Administration

These are the key statistics in your commandery.

[[img:help_mode_province_money]][[/img]] [[b]]Income[[/b]] is the most important resource a commandery can generate. Try to maximise income by focusing your construction projects on certain [[b]]income types[[/b]] (like [[b]]commerce[[/b]] or [[b]]peasantry[[/b]]), and on synergies within these.

[[img:help_mode_province_food]][[/img]] [[b]]Food[[/b]] can be produced and consumed in your commanderies. This value shows you the [[b]]local balance[[/b]] of food. A negative balance is not harmful as long as other commanderies can compensate for it. Dedicate certain commanderies to food production to create [[b]]bread baskets[[/b]] in your realm.
Make sure to secure certain resource settlements for efficient income of food, such as [[b]]farms[[/b]] or [[b]]fishing ports[[/b]]. You can also produce food in your {{tr:map_province}} capital by constructing buildings in the [[b]]land development[[/b]] chain, but this is less efficient than dedicated resource settlements.

[[img:help_mode_province_public_order]][[/img]] If [[b]]{{tr:public_order}}[[/b]] reaches -100, [[b]]rebellions[[/b]] will spawn. {{tr:help_mode_public_order_province}}

string.last_approved_text: Commandery Essentials

Commanderies can have a number of [[b]]resource settlements[[/b]] that provide valuable bonuses to the commandery and your faction. When specialising your commanderies, it is worth looking at the resources available to you. This can inform whether a commandery should specialise in [[b]]food[[/b]] production, or in [[b]]income[[/b]] generation.

When specialising your commanderies, it is worth looking at the resources available to you. This can inform whether a commandery should specialise in [[b]]food[[/b]] production, or in [[b]]income[[/b]] generation.

string.last_approved_text: [[b]]Resource settlements[[/b]] can be a valuable target of your expansion. If you own the commandery capital already, they enable you to create powerful synergies, but even if you do not own the capital, its resource settlements will still give bonuses to you.

campaign_localised_strings.string: [[b]]Resource settlements[[/b]] can be a valuable target of your expansion. If you own the commandery capital already, they enable you to create powerful synergies, but even if you do not own the capital, its resource settlements will still give bonuses to you.

string.last_approved_text: Resource Settlements (Not owned)
Resource Settlements

These are the [[b]]buildings[[/b]] constructed in this commandery capital. Buildings have very different purposes and often synergise with each other. Think about specialising your commanderies for particular purposes and identify buildings that support this direction.

Specialising in [[b]]food[[/b]] production or [[b]]income[[/b]] is a valid consideration. When specialising in income, focus on one of the three key [[b]]income types[[/b]]:

[[b]]Peasantry[[/b]] is income from agriculture and similar sources, which benefits greatly from a higher population.

[[b]]Commerce[[/b]] is income from markets and merchants, which benefits greatly from the construction of commerce centres, where buildings boost each other's income.

[[b]]Industry[[/b]] is income from mines and other resources, which is a good standalone source of income which requires less synergy-building.

string.last_approved_text: These are the [[b]]buildings[[/b]] constructed in this commandery capital, owned by another faction. If you plan to capture this settlement, you will be able to loot it after the battle, earning income relative to the development level of its buildings. Additionally, some buildings might require [[b]]conversion[[/b]] before they can be further developed, while others might be entirely unique to the current owner.

string.last_approved_text: Buildings (Not owned)

[[img:help_mode_province_reserves]][[/img]] [[b]]Reserves[[/b]] are key to replenishing your armies' [[b]]military supplies[[/b]]. It also determines how long besieged [[b]]commandery capitals[[/b]] will be able to hold out. Reserves are filled when your [[b]]faction-wide food balance[[/b]] is positive, but will deplete if your faction is suffering from a food shortage.\n\n[[img:help_mode_province_population]][[/img]] [[b]]Population[[/b]] is key to the economic growth of your commanderies, providing strong bonuses to your income from the [[b]]peasantry[[/b]] and [[b]]replenishment[[/b]] bonuses for your armies. Keep your population growing by constructing buildings and watching for other opportunities, such as [[b]]assignments[[/b]].

Keep your population growing by constructing buildings and watching for other opportunities, such as [[b]]assignments[[/b]].

string.last_approved_text: Reserves & Population
Reforms & Technologies

These are the possible [[b]]actions[[/b]] that can be performed by your spy.

[[img:help_mode_spies_role_noble]][[/img]] Actions that can be performed by [[b]]court nobles[[/b]].
[[img:help_mode_spies_role_admin]][[/img]] Actions that can be performed by [[b]]administrators[[/b]].
[[img:help_mode_spies_role_general]][[/img]] Actions that can be performed by [[b]]generals[[/b]].
[[img:help_mode_spies_role_family]][[/img]] Actions that can be performed by [[b]]family members[[/b]].

Depending on their role and [[b]]position[[/b]] within the target faction, different actions are available, each one coming with a cost in cover and network points.

[[img:help_mode_spies_cover]][[/img]] [[b]]Cover points[[/b]] represent a character's personal cover. An action can only be performed if a spy has built up [[b]]enough cover[[/b]] for this action. After an action is performed, these points must replenish before it is safe to undertake another one. The maximum number of cover points is 100.

[[img:help_mode_spies_network]][[/img]] [[b]]Network points[[/b]] are shared amongst characters spying on the [[b]]same faction[[/b]]. Every action performed costs a certain amount of network points, but there might be a [[b]]hidden cost[[/b]] increase based on the target faction's [[b]]defences[[/b]] against espionage. If the actual network cost exceeds the base amount, you will be prompted with a choice to spend the additional cost or not. If you decide not to, or if you cannot, the spy will be [[b]]caught[[/b]].

You can never be sure about your target faction's defences, so be prepared to expend your [[b]]network points[[/b]].

Not all characters will be able to spy on other factions.

string.last_approved_text: Active Spies

This is your list of potential spies. Only characters [[b]]eligible[[/b]] to engage in espionage activities will be displayed here.

[[img:help_mode_spies_upkeep]][[/img]] This is the [[b]]upkeep[[/b]] that must be paid in order for this spy to operate, which depends how loyal and [[b]]satisfied[[/b]] they are with you – spies who are generally disloyal will require more gold to sustain.

[[img:help_mode_spies_satisfaction]][[/img]] This is this character’s [[b]]satisfaction[[/b]], which has an impact on their upkeep. Consider sending out more loyal and satisfied characters to build up your espionage network.

Be mindful, however, as a character's satisfaction is kept [[b]]constant[[/b]] while spying, and they will have a separate satisfaction value towards the [[b]]target faction[[/b]]. Should this value reach 95, the spy will [[b]]switch allegiance[[/b]] and join the enemy!

[[img:help_mode_spies_grudges]][[/img]] Characters can have [[b]]grudges[[/b]] towards a faction; in such cases, the spy will not be able to infiltrate this particular faction, but may select another target.

string.last_approved_text: Spy Deployment

These are your [[b]]known factions[[/b]] and therefore are potential targets for espionage. Sending out spies to infiltrate your enemies may be the obvious choice, but consider that espionage is also a matter of [[b]]strategy[[/b]] and [[b]]time[[/b]]. The longer a spy infiltrates another faction, the more effective and powerful his influence may get.\n\nThis means that in some cases, it might be best to infiltrate your allies and friends instead - it all depends on your [[b]]long-term strategy[[/b]]...

[[b]]Victory Types[[/b]]
Standard: reach the rank of Victorious Prince.

Co-operative: combine your strength by signing a shared mandate diplomatic deal.

Head-to-Head: destroy the other player, or compete with one another to be the first to meet the victory conditions.

campaign_localised_strings.string:
[[b]]Victory Types[[/b]]
Standard: reach the rank of Victorious Prince.

Co-operative: combine your strength by signing a shared mandate diplomatic deal.

Head-to-Head: destroy the other player, or compete with one another to be the first to meet the victory conditions.

string.last_approved_text:
Your [[b]]alignments[[/b]] are a unique feature of the Eight Princes campaign.

[[b]]Dilemmas[[/b]] occur throughout the course of the campaign and give opportunities to increase your [[b]]alignment[[/b]] values.

Each alignment level gives an increasingly more powerful effects to your faction.

Hovering over an alignment allows you to see your current alignment, the amount of points required for the next level, the effects granted by your current level and the effects granted by the next level.

campaign_localised_strings.string:

Each alignment level gives an increasingly more powerful effects to your faction.

Hovering over an alignment allows you to see your current alignment, the amount of points required for the next level, the effects granted by your current level and the effects granted by the next level.
